title: 孟子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 公孫丑問曰：「夫子當路於齊，管仲、晏子之功，可復許乎？」
passages.en: Gong Sun Chou asked Mencius, saying, 'Master, if you were to obtain the ordering of the government in Qi, could you promise yourself to accomplish anew such results as those realized by Guan Zhong and Yan?'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「子誠齊人也，知管仲、晏子而已矣。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'You are indeed a true man of Qi. You know about Guan Zhong and Yan, and nothing more.

passages.zh: 或問乎曾西曰；『吾子與子路孰賢？』
passages.en: Some one asked Zeng Xi, saying, "Sir, to which do you give the superiority, to yourself or to Zi Lu?"

passages.zh: 曾西蹴然曰：『吾先子之所畏也。』
passages.en: Zeng Zi looked uneasy, and said, "He was an object of veneration to my grandfather."

passages.zh: 曰：『然則吾子與管仲孰賢？』
passages.en: "Then," pursued the other, "Do you give the superiority to yourself or to Guan Zhong?"

passages.zh: 曾西艴然不悅，曰：『爾何曾比予於管仲？
passages.en: Zeng Zi, flushed with anger and displeased, said, "How dare you compare me with Guan Zhong?

passages.zh: 管仲得君，如彼其專也；行乎國政，如彼其久也；功烈，如彼其卑也。
passages.en: Considering how entirely Guan Zhong possessed the confidence of his prince, how long he enjoyed the direction of the government of the State, and how low, after all, was what he accomplished -

passages.zh: 爾何曾比予於是？』」
passages.en: how is it that you liken me to him?"

passages.zh: 曰：「管仲，曾西之所不為也，而子為我願之乎？」
passages.en: Thus,' concluded Mencius, 'Zeng Xi would not play Guan Zhong, and is it what you desire for me that I should do so?'

passages.zh: 曰：「管仲以其君霸，晏子以其君顯。
passages.en: Gong Sun Chou said, 'Guan Zhong raised his prince to be the leader of all the other princes, and Yan made his prince illustrious,

passages.zh: 管仲、晏子猶不足為與？」
passages.en: and do you still think it would not be enough for you to do what they did?'

passages.zh: 曰：「以齊王，由反手也。」
passages.en: Mencius answered, 'To raise Qi to the royal dignity would be as easy as it is to turn round the hand.'

passages.zh: 曰：「若是，則弟子之惑滋甚。
passages.en: 'So!' returned the other. 'The perplexity of your disciple is hereby very much increased.

passages.zh: 且以文王之德，百年而後崩，猶未洽於天下；武王、周公繼之，然後大行。
passages.en: There was king Wen, moreover, with all the virtue which belonged to him; and who did not die till he had reached a hundred years - and still his influence had not penetrated throughout the kingdom. It required king Wu and the duke of Zhou to continue his course, before that influence greatly prevailed.

passages.zh: 今言王若易然，則文王不足法與？」
passages.en: Now you say that the royal dignity might be so easily obtained - is king Wen then not a sufficient object for imitation?'

passages.zh: 曰：「文王何可當也？
passages.en: Mencius said, 'How can king Wen be matched?

passages.zh: 由湯至於武丁，賢聖之君六七作。
passages.en: From Tang to Wu Ding there had appeared six or seven worthy and sage sovereigns.

passages.zh: 天下歸殷久矣，久則難變也。
passages.en: The kingdom had been attached to Yin for a long time, and this length of time made a change difficult.

passages.zh: 武丁朝諸侯有天下，猶運之掌也。
passages.en: Wu Ding had all the princes coming to his court, and possessed the kingdom as if it had been a thing which he moved round in his palm.

passages.zh: 紂之去武丁未久也，其故家遺俗，流風善政，猶有存者；又有微子、微仲、王子比干、箕子、膠鬲皆賢人也，相與輔相之，故久而後失之也。
passages.en: Then, Zhou was removed from Wu Ding by no great interval of time. There were still remaining some of the ancient families and of the old manners, of the influence also which had emanated from the earlier sovereigns, and of their good government. Moreover, there were the viscount of Wei and his second son, their Royal Highnesses Bi Gan and the viscount of Qi, and Jiao Ge, all men of ability and virtue, who gave their joint assistance to Zhou in his government. In consequence of these things, it took a long time for him to lose the throne.

passages.zh: 尺地莫非其有也，一民莫非其臣也，然而文王猶方百里起，是以難也。
passages.en: There was not a foot of ground which he did not possess. There was not one of all the people who was not his subject. So it was on his side, and king Wen at his beginning had only a territory of one hundred square li. On all these accounts, it was difficult for him immediately to attain to the royal dignity.

passages.zh: 齊人有言曰：『雖有智慧，不如乘勢；雖有鎡基，不如待時。』
passages.en: The people of Qi have a saying - "A man may have wisdom and discernment, but that is not like embracing the favourable opportunity. A man may have instruments of husbandry, but that is not like waiting for the farming seasons."

passages.zh: 「今時則易然也。
passages.en: The present time is one in which the royal dignity may be easily attained.

passages.zh: 夏后、殷、周之盛，地未有過千里者也，而齊有其地矣；雞鳴狗吠相聞，而達乎四境，而齊有其民矣。
passages.en: In the flourishing periods of the Xia, Yin, and Zhou dynasties, the royal domain did not exceed a thousand li, and Qi embraces so much territory. Cocks crow and dogs bark to one another, all the way to the four borders of the State - so Qi possesses the people.

passages.zh: 地不改辟矣，民不改聚矣，行仁政而王，莫之能禦也。
passages.en: No change is needed for the enlarging of its territory; no change is needed for the collecting of a population. If its ruler will put in practice a benevolent government, no power will be able to prevent his becoming sovereign.

passages.zh: 且王者之不作，未有疏於此時者也；民之憔悴於虐政，未有甚於此時者也。
passages.en: Moreover, never was there a time farther removed than the present from the rise of a true sovereign: never was there a time when the sufferings of the people from tyrannical government were more intense than the present.

passages.zh: 飢者易為食，渴者易為飲。
passages.en: The hungry readily partake of any food, and the thirsty of any drink.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『德之流行，速於置郵而傳命。』
passages.en: Confucius said, "The flowing progress of virtue is more rapid than the transmission of royal orders by stages and couriers."

passages.zh: 當今之時，萬乘之國行仁政，民之悅之，猶解倒懸也。
passages.en: At the present time, in a country of ten thousand chariots, let benevolent government be put in practice, and the people will be delighted with it, as if they were relieved from hanging by the heels.

passages.zh: 故事半古之人，功必倍之，惟此時為然。」
passages.en: With half the merit of the ancients, double their achievements is sure to be realized. It is only at this time that such could be the case.'

passages.zh: 公孫丑問曰：「夫子加齊之卿相，得行道焉，雖由此霸王不異矣。
passages.en: Gong Sun Chou asked Mencius, saying, 'Master, if you were to be appointed a high noble and the prime minister of Qi, so as to be able to carry your principles into practice, though you should thereupon raise the ruler to the headship of all the other princes, or even to the royal dignity, it would not be to be wondered at.

passages.zh: 如此，則動心否乎？」
passages.en: In such a position would your mind be perturbed or not?'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「否。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'No.

passages.zh: 我四十不動心。」
passages.en: At forty, I attained to an unperturbed mind.'

passages.zh: 曰：「若是，則夫子過孟賁遠矣。」
passages.en: Chou said, 'Since it is so with you, my Master, you are far beyond Meng Ben.'

passages.zh: 曰：「是不難，告子先我不動心。」
passages.en: 'The mere attainment,' said Mencius, 'is not difficult. The scholar Gao had attained to an unperturbed mind at an earlier period of life than I did.'

passages.zh: 曰：「不動心有道乎？」
passages.en: Chou asked, 'Is there any way to an unperturbed mind?'

passages.zh: 曰：「有。
passages.en: The answer was, 'Yes.

passages.zh: 北宮黝之養勇也，不膚撓，不目逃，思以一豪挫於人，若撻之於市朝。
passages.en: Bei Gong You had this way of nourishing his valour: He did not flinch from any strokes at his body. He did not turn his eyes aside from any thrusts at them. He considered that the slightest push from any one was the same as if he were beaten before the crowds in the market-place,

passages.zh: 不受於褐寬博，亦不受於萬乘之君。
passages.en: and that what he would not receive from a common man in his loose large garments of hair, neither should he receive from a prince of ten thousand chariots.

passages.zh: 視刺萬乘之君，若刺褐夫。
passages.en: He viewed stabbing a prince of ten thousand chariots just as stabbing a fellow dressed in cloth of hair.

passages.zh: 無嚴諸侯。
passages.en: He feared not any of all the princes.

passages.zh: 惡聲至，必反之。
passages.en: A bad word addressed to him be always returned.

passages.zh: 孟施舍之所養勇也，曰：『視不勝猶勝也。
passages.en: Meng Shi She had this way of nourishing his valour: He said, "I look upon not conquering and conquering in the same way.

passages.zh: 量敵而後進，慮勝而後會，是畏三軍者也。
passages.en: To measure the enemy and then advance; to calculate the chances of victory and then engage - this is to stand in awe of the opposing force.

passages.zh: 舍豈能為必勝哉？
passages.en: How can I make certain of conquering?

passages.zh: 能無懼而已矣。』
passages.en: I can only rise superior to all fear."

passages.zh: 孟施舍似曾子，北宮黝似子夏。
passages.en: Meng Shi She resembled the philosopher Zeng. Bei Gong You resembled Zi Xia.

passages.zh: 夫二子之勇，未知其孰賢，然而孟施舍守約也。
passages.en: I do not know to the valour of which of the two the superiority should be ascribed, but yet Meng Shi She attended to what was of the greater importance.

passages.zh: 昔者曾子謂子襄曰：『子好勇乎？
passages.en: Formerly, the philosopher Zeng said to Zi Xiang, "Do you love valour?

passages.zh: 吾嘗聞大勇於夫子矣：自反而不縮，雖褐寬博，吾不惴焉；自反而縮，雖千萬人，吾往矣。』
passages.en: I heard an account of great valour from the Master. It speaks thus: 'If, on self-examination, I find that I am not upright, shall I not be in fear even of a poor man in his loose garments of hair-cloth? If, on self-examination, I find that I am upright, I will go forward against thousands and tens of thousands.'"

passages.zh: 孟施舍之守氣，又不如曾子之守約也。」
passages.en: Yet, what Meng Shi She maintained, being merely his physical energy, was after all inferior to what the philosopher Zeng maintained, which was indeed of the most importance.'

passages.zh: 曰：「敢問夫子之不動心，與告子之不動心，可得聞與？」
passages.en: Gong Sun Chou said, 'May I venture to ask an explanation from you, Master, of how you maintain an unperturbed mind, and how the philosopher Gao does the same?'

passages.zh: 「告子曰：『不得於言，勿求於心；不得於心，勿求於氣。』
passages.en: Mencius answered, 'Gao says, "What is not attained in words is not to be sought for in the mind; what produces dissatisfaction in the mind, is not to be helped by passion-effort."

passages.zh: 不得於心，勿求於氣，可；不得於言，勿求於心，不可。
passages.en: This last, when there is unrest in the mind, not to seek for relief from passion-effort, may be conceded. But not to seek in the mind for what is not attained in words cannot be conceded.

passages.zh: 夫志，氣之帥也；氣，體之充也。
passages.en: The will is the leader of the passion-nature. The passion-nature pervades and animates the body.

passages.zh: 夫志至焉，氣次焉。
passages.en: The will is first and chief, and the passion-nature is subordinate to it.

passages.zh: 故曰：『持其志，無暴其氣。』」
passages.en: Therefore I say, Maintain firm the will, and do no violence to the passion-nature.'

passages.zh: 「既曰『志至焉，氣次焉』，又曰『持其志無暴其氣』者，何也？」
passages.en: Chou observed, 'Since you say "The will is chief, and the passion-nature is subordinate," how do you also say, "Maintain firm the will, and do no violence to the passion-nature?"'

passages.zh: 曰：「志壹則動氣，氣壹則動志也。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'When it is the will alone which is active, it moves the passion-nature. When it is the passion-nature alone which is active, it moves the will.

passages.zh: 今夫蹶者趨者，是氣也，而反動其心。」
passages.en: For instance now, in the case of a man falling or running, that is from the passion-nature, and yet it moves the mind.'

passages.zh: 「敢問夫子惡乎長？」
passages.en: 'I venture to ask,' said Chou again, 'wherein you, Master, surpass Gao.'

passages.zh: 曰：「我知言，我善養吾浩然之氣。」
passages.en: Mencius told him, 'I understand words. I am skilful in nourishing my vast, flowing passion-nature.'

passages.zh: 「敢問何謂浩然之氣？」
passages.en: Chou pursued, 'I venture to ask what you mean by your vast, flowing passion-nature!'

passages.zh: 曰：「難言也。
passages.en: The reply was, 'It is difficult to describe it.

passages.zh: 其為氣也，至大至剛，以直養而無害，則塞于天地之閒。
passages.en: This is the passion-nature: It is exceedingly great, and exceedingly strong. Being nourished by rectitude, and sustaining no injury, it fills up all between heaven and earth.

passages.zh: 其為氣也，配義與道；無是，餒也。
passages.en: This is the passion-nature: It is the mate and assistant of righteousness and reason. Without it, man is in a state of starvation.

passages.zh: 是集義所生者，非義襲而取之也。
passages.en: It is produced by the accumulation of righteous deeds; it is not to be obtained by incidental acts of righteousness.

passages.zh: 行有不慊於心，則餒矣。
passages.en: If the mind does not feel complacency in the conduct, the nature becomes starved.

passages.zh: 我故曰，告子未嘗知義，以其外之也。
passages.en: I therefore said, "Gao has never understood righteousness, because he makes it something external."

passages.zh: 必有事焉而勿正，心勿忘，勿助長也。
passages.en: There must be the constant practice of this righteousness, but without the object of thereby nourishing the passion-nature. Let not the mind forget its work, but let there be no assisting the growth of that nature.

passages.zh: 無若宋人然：宋人有閔其苗之不長而揠之者，芒芒然歸。
passages.en: Let us not be like the man of Song. There was a man of Song, who was grieved that his growing corn was not longer, and so he pulled it up. Having done this, he returned home, looking very stupid,

passages.zh: 謂其人曰：『今日病矣，予助苗長矣。』
passages.en: and said to his people, "I am tired to-day. I have been helping the corn to grow long."

passages.zh: 其子趨而往視之，苗則槁矣。
passages.en: His son ran to look at it, and found the corn all withered.

passages.zh: 天下之不助苗長者寡矣。
passages.en: There are few in the world, who do not deal with their passion-nature, as if they were assisting the corn to grow long.

passages.zh: 以為無益而舍之者，不耘苗者也；助之長者，揠苗者也。
passages.en: Some indeed consider it of no benefit to them, and let it alone - they do not weed their corn. They who assist it to grow long, pull out their corn.

passages.zh: 非徒無益，而又害之。」
passages.en: What they do is not only of no benefit to the nature, but it also injures it.'

passages.zh: 「何謂知言？」
passages.en: Gong Sun Chou further asked, 'What do you mean by saying that you understand whatever words you hear?'

passages.zh: 曰：「詖辭知其所蔽，淫辭知其所陷，邪辭知其所離，遁辭知其所窮。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'When words are one-sided, I know how the mind of the speaker is clouded over. When words are extravagant, I know how the mind is fallen and sunk. When words are all-depraved, I know how the mind has departed from principle. When words are evasive, I know how the mind is at its wit's end.

passages.zh: 生於其心，害於其政；發於其政，害於其事。
passages.en: These evils growing in the mind, do injury to government, and, displayed in the government, are hurtful to the conduct of affairs.

passages.zh: 聖人復起，必從吾言矣。」
passages.en: When a Sage shall again arise, he will certainly follow my words.'

passages.zh: 「宰我、子貢善為說辭，冉牛、閔子、顏淵善言德行。
passages.en: On this Chou observed, 'Zai Wo and Zi Gong were skilful in speaking. Ran Niu, the disciple Min, and Yan Yuan, while their words were good, were distinguished for their virtuous conduct.

passages.zh: 孔子兼之，曰：『我於辭命則不能也。』
passages.en: Confucius united the qualities of the disciples in himself, but still he said, "In the matter of speeches, I am not competent."

passages.zh: 然則夫子既聖矣乎？」
passages.en: Then, Master, have you attained to be a Sage?'

passages.zh: 曰：「惡！
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Oh!

passages.zh: 是何言也？
passages.en: what words are these?

passages.zh: 昔者子貢、問於孔子曰：『夫子聖矣乎？』
passages.en: Formerly Zi Gong asked Confucius, saying, "Master, are you a Sage?"

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『聖則吾不能，我學不厭而教不倦也。』
passages.en: Confucius answered him, "A Sage is what I cannot rise to. I learn without satiety, and teach without being tired."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：『學不厭，智也；教不倦，仁也。
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "You learn without satiety - that shows your wisdom. You teach without being tired - that shows your benevolence.

passages.zh: 仁且智，夫子既聖矣！』
passages.en: Benevolent and wise - Master, you ARE a Sage."

passages.zh: 夫聖，孔子不居，是何言也？」
passages.en: Now, since Confucius would not allow himself to be regarded as a Sage, what words were those?'

passages.zh: 「昔者竊聞之：子夏、子游、子張皆有聖人之一體，冉牛、閔子、顏淵則具體而微。
passages.en: Chou said, 'Formerly, I once heard this: Zi Xia, Zi You, and Zi Zhang had each one member of the Sage. Ran Niu, the disciple Min, and Yan Yuan had all the members, but in small proportions.

passages.zh: 敢問所安。」
passages.en: I venture to ask, With which of these are you pleased to rank yourself?'

passages.zh: 曰：「姑舍是。」
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'Let us drop speaking about these, if you please.'

passages.zh: 曰：「伯夷、伊尹何如？」
passages.en: Chou then asked, 'What do you say of Bo Yi and Yi Yin?'

passages.zh: 曰：「不同道。
passages.en: 'Their ways were different from mine,' said Mencius.

passages.zh: 非其君不事，非其民不使；治則進，亂則退，伯夷也。
passages.en: 'Not to serve a prince whom he did not esteem, nor command a people whom he did not approve; in a time of good government to take office, and on the occurrence of confusion to retire - this was the way of Bo Yi.

passages.zh: 何事非君，何使非民；治亦進，亂亦進，伊尹也。
passages.en: To say "Whom may I not serve? My serving him makes him my ruler. What people may I not command? My commanding them makes them my people." In a time of good government to take office, and when disorder prevailed, also to take office - that was the way of Yi Yin.

passages.zh: 可以仕則仕，可以止則止，可以久則久，可以速則速，孔子也。
passages.en: When it was proper to go into office, then to go into it; when it was proper to keep retired from office, then to keep retired from it; when it was proper to continue in it long, then to continue in it long - when it was proper to withdraw from it quickly, then to withdraw quickly - that was the way of Confucius.

passages.zh: 皆古聖人也，吾未能有行焉；乃所願，則學孔子也。」
passages.en: These were all sages of antiquity, and I have not attained to do what they did. But what I wish to do is to learn to be like Confucius.'

passages.zh: 「伯夷、伊尹於孔子，若是班乎？」
passages.en: Chou said, 'Comparing Bo Yi and Yi Yin with Confucius, are they to be placed in the same rank?'

passages.zh: 曰：「否。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'No.

passages.zh: 自有生民以來，未有孔子也。」
passages.en: Since there were living men until now, there never was another Confucius.'

passages.zh: 曰：「然則有同與？」
passages.en: Chou said, 'Then, did they have any points of agreement with him?'

passages.zh: 曰：「有。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Yes.

passages.zh: 得百里之地而君之，皆能以朝諸侯有天下。
passages.en: If they had been sovereigns over a hundred li of territory, they would, all of them, have brought all the princes to attend in their court, and have obtained the throne.

passages.zh: 行一不義、殺一不辜而得天下，皆不為也。
passages.en: And none of them, in order to obtain the throne, would have committed one act of unrighteousness, or put to death one innocent person.

passages.zh: 是則同。」
passages.en: In those things they agreed with him.'

passages.zh: 曰：「敢問其所以異？」
passages.en: Chou said, 'I venture to ask wherein he differed from them.'

passages.zh: 曰：「宰我、子貢、有若智足以知聖人。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'Zai Wo, Zi Gong, and You Ruo had wisdom sufficient to know the sage.

passages.zh: 汙，不至阿其所好。
passages.en: Even had they been ranking themselves low, they would not have demeaned themselves to flatter their favourite.

passages.zh: 宰我曰：『以予觀於夫子，賢於堯舜遠矣。』
passages.en: Now, Zai Wo said, "According to my view of our Master, he was far superior to Yao and Shun."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：『見其禮而知其政，聞其樂而知其德。
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "By viewing the ceremonial ordinances of a prince, we know the character of his government. By hearing his music, we know the character of his virtue.

passages.zh: 由百世之後，等百世之王，莫之能違也。
passages.en: After the lapse of a hundred ages I can arrange, according to their merits, the kings of a hundred ages - not one of them can escape me.

passages.zh: 自生民以來，未有夫子也。』
passages.en: From the birth of mankind till now, there has never been another like our Master."

passages.zh: 有若曰：『豈惟民哉？
passages.en: You Ruo said, "Is it only among men that it is so?

passages.zh: 麒麟之於走獸，鳳凰之於飛鳥，太山之於丘垤，河海之於行潦，類也。
passages.en: There is the Qi-lin among quadrupeds, the Feng-huang among birds, the Tai mountain among mounds and ant-hills, and rivers and seas among rain-pools. Though different in degree, they are the same in kind.

passages.zh: 聖人之於民，亦類也。
passages.en: So the sages among mankind are also the same in kind.

passages.zh: 出於其類，拔乎其萃，自生民以來，未有盛於孔子也。』」
passages.en: But they stand out from their fellows, and rise above the level, and from the birth of mankind till now, there never has been one so complete as Confucius."'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「以力假仁者霸，霸必有大國，以德行仁者王，王不待大。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'He who, using force, makes a pretence to benevolence is the leader of the princes. A leader of the princes requires a large kingdom. He who, using virtue, practises benevolence is the sovereign of the kingdom. To become the sovereign of the kingdom, a prince need not wait for a large kingdom.

passages.zh: 湯以七十里，文王以百里。
passages.en: Tang did it with only seventy li, and king Wen with only a hundred.

passages.zh: 以力服人者，非心服也，力不贍也；以德服人者，中心悅而誠服也，如七十子之服孔子也。
passages.en: When one by force subdues men, they do not submit to him in heart. They submit, because their strength is not adequate to resist. When one subdues men by virtue, in their hearts' core they are pleased, and sincerely submit, as was the case with the seventy disciples in their submission to Confucius.

passages.zh: 《詩》云：『自西自東，自南自北，無思不服。』此之謂也。」
passages.en: What is said in the Book of Poetry, "From the west, from the east, From the south, from the north, There was not one who thought of refusing submission," is an illustration of this.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「仁則榮，不仁則辱。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Benevolence brings glory to a prince, and the opposite of it brings disgrace.

passages.zh: 今惡辱而居不仁，是猶惡溼而居下也。
passages.en: For the princes of the present day to hate disgrace and yet to live complacently doing what is not benevolent, is like hating moisture and yet living in a low situation.

passages.zh: 如惡之，莫如貴德而尊士，賢者在位，能者在職。
passages.en: If a prince hates disgrace, the best course for him to pursue, is to esteem virtue and honour virtuous scholars, giving the worthiest among them places of dignity, and the able offices of trust.

passages.zh: 國家閒暇，及是時明其政刑。
passages.en: When throughout his kingdom there is leisure and rest from external troubles, let him, taking advantage of such a season, clearly digest the principles of his government with its legal sanctions,

passages.zh: 雖大國，必畏之矣。
passages.en: and then even great kingdoms will be constrained to stand in awe of him.

passages.zh: 《詩》云：『迨天之未陰雨，徹彼桑土，綢繆牖戶。
passages.en: It is said in the Book of Poetry, "Before the heavens were dark with rain, I gathered the bark from the roots of the mulberry trees, And wove it closely to form the window and door of my nest;

passages.zh: 今此下民，或敢侮予？』
passages.en: Now, I thought, ye people below, Perhaps ye will not dare to insult me."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『為此詩者，其知道乎！
passages.en: Confucius said, "Did not he who made this ode understand the way of governing?"

passages.zh: 能治其國家，誰敢侮之？』
passages.en: If a prince is able rightly to govern his kingdom, who will dare to insult him?

passages.zh: 今國家閒暇，及是時般樂怠敖，是自求禍也。
passages.en: But now the princes take advantage of the time when throughout their kingdoms there is leisure and rest from external troubles, to abandon themselves to pleasure and indolent indifference - they in fact seek for calamities for themselves.

passages.zh: 禍褔無不自己求之者。
passages.en: Calamity and happiness in all cases are men's own seeking.

passages.zh: 《詩》云：『永言配命，自求多褔。』
passages.en: This is illustrated by what is said in the Book of Poetry - Be always studious to be in harmony with the ordinances of God, So you will certainly get for yourself much happiness;"

passages.zh: 《太甲》曰：『天作孽，猶可違；自作孽，不可活。』此之謂也。」
passages.en: and by the passage of the Tai Jia, "When Heaven sends down calamities, it is still possible to escape from them; when we occasion the calamities ourselves, it is not possible any longer to live."'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「尊賢使能，俊傑在位，則天下之士皆悅而願立於其朝矣。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'If a ruler give honour to men of talents and virtue and employ the able, so that offices shall all be filled by individuals of distinction and mark - then all the scholars of the kingdom will be pleased, and wish to stand in his court.

passages.zh: 市廛而不征，法而不廛，則天下之商皆悅而願藏於其市矣。
passages.en: If, in the market-place of his capital, he levy a ground-rent on the shops but do not tax the goods, or enforce the proper regulations without levying a ground-rent - then all the traders of the kingdom will be pleased, and wish to store their goods in his market-place.

passages.zh: 關譏而不征，則天下之旅皆悅而願出於其路矣。
passages.en: If, at his frontier-passes, there be an inspection of persons, but no taxes charged on goods or other articles, then all the travellers of the kingdom will be pleased, and wish to make their tours on his roads.

passages.zh: 耕者助而不稅，則天下之農皆悅而願耕於其野矣。
passages.en: If he require that the husbandmen give their mutual aid to cultivate the public feld, and exact no other taxes from them - then all the husbandmen of the kingdom will be pleased, and wish to plough in his fields.

passages.zh: 廛無夫里之布，則天下之民皆悅而願為之氓矣。
passages.en: If from the occupiers of the shops in his market-place he do not exact the fine of the individual idler, or of the hamlet's quota of cloth, then all the people of the kingdom will be pleased, and wish to come and be his people.

passages.zh: 信能行此五者，則鄰國之民仰之若父母矣。
passages.en: If a ruler can truly practise these five things, then the people in the neighbouring kingdoms will look up to him as a parent.

passages.zh: 率其子弟，攻其父母，自生民以來，未有能濟者也。
passages.en: From the first birth of mankind till now, never has any one led children to attack their parent, and succeeded in his design.

passages.zh: 如此，則無敵於天下。
passages.en: Thus, such a ruler will not have an enemy in all the kingdom,

passages.zh: 無敵於天下者，天吏也。
passages.en: and he who has no enemy in the kingdom is the minister of Heaven.

passages.zh: 然而不王者，未之有也。」
passages.en: Never has there been a ruler in such a case who did not attain to the royal dignity.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「人皆有不忍人之心。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'All men have a mind which cannot bear to see the sufferings of others.

passages.zh: 先王有不忍人之心，斯有不忍人之政矣。
passages.en: 'The ancient kings had this commiserating mind, and they, as a matter of course, had likewise a commiserating government.

passages.zh: 以不忍人之心，行不忍人之政，治天下可運之掌上。
passages.en: When with a commiserating mind was practised a commiserating government, to rule the kingdom was as easy a matter as to make anything go round in the palm.

passages.zh: 所以謂人皆有不忍人之心者，今人乍見孺子將入於井，皆有怵惕惻隱之心。
passages.en: When I say that all men have a mind which cannot bear to see the sufferings of others, my meaning may be illustrated thus: even now-a-days, if men suddenly see a child about to fall into a well, they will without exception experience a feeling of alarm and distress.

passages.zh: 非所以內交於孺子之父母也，非所以要譽於鄉黨朋友也，非惡其聲而然也。
passages.en: They will feel so, not as a ground on which they may gain the favour of the child's parents, nor as a ground on which they may seek the praise of their neighbours and friends, nor from a dislike to the reputation of having been unmoved by such a thing.

passages.zh: 由是觀之，無惻隱之心，非人也；無羞惡之心，非人也；無辭讓之心，非人也；無是非之心，非人也。
passages.en: From this case we may perceive that the feeling of commiseration is essential to man, that the feeling of shame and dislike is essential to man, that the feeling of modesty and complaisance is essential to man, and that the feeling of approving and disapproving is essential to man.

passages.zh: 惻隱之心，仁之端也；羞惡之心，義之端也；辭讓之心，禮之端也；是非之心，智之端也。
passages.en: The feeling of commiseration is the principle of benevolence. The feeling of shame and dislike is the principle of righteousness. The feeling of modesty and complaisance is the principle of propriety. The feeling of approving and disapproving is the principle of knowledge.

passages.zh: 人之有是四端也，猶其有四體也。
passages.en: Men have these four principles just as they have their four limbs.

passages.zh: 有是四端而自謂不能者，自賊者也；謂其君不能者，賊其君者也。
passages.en: When men, having these four principles, yet say of themselves that they cannot develop them, they play the thief with themselves, and he who says of his prince that he cannot develop them plays the thief with his prince.

passages.zh: 凡有四端於我者，知皆擴而充之矣，若火之始然，泉之始達。
passages.en: Since all men have these four principles in themselves, let them know to give them all their development and completion, and the issue will be like that of fire which has begun to burn, or that of a spring which has begun to find vent.

passages.zh: 苟能充之，足以保四海；苟不充之，不足以事父母。」
passages.en: Let them have their complete development, and they will suffice to love and protect all within the four seas. Let them be denied that development, and they will not suffice for a man to serve his parents with.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「矢人豈不仁於函人哉？
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Is the arrow-maker less benevolent than the maker of armour of defence?

passages.zh: 矢人唯恐不傷人，函人唯恐傷人。
passages.en: And yet, the arrow-maker's only fear is lest men should not be hurt, and the armour-maker's only fear is lest men should be hurt.

passages.zh: 巫匠亦然，故術不可不慎也。
passages.en: So it is with the priest and the coffin-maker. The choice of a profession, therefore, is a thing in which great caution is required.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『里仁為美。
passages.en: Confucius said, "It is virtuous manners which constitute the excellence of a neighbourhood.

passages.zh: 擇不處仁，焉得智？』
passages.en: If a man, in selecting a residence, do not fix on one where such prevail, how can he be wise?"

passages.zh: 夫仁，天之尊爵也，人之安宅也。
passages.en: Now, benevolence is the most honourable dignity conferred by Heaven, and the quiet home in which man should dwell.

passages.zh: 莫之禦而不仁，是不智也。
passages.en: Since no one can hinder us from being so, if yet we are not benevolent - this is being not wise.

passages.zh: 不仁、不智、無禮、無義，人役也。
passages.en: From the want of benevolence and the want of wisdom will ensue the entire absence of propriety and righteousness;-- he who is in such a case must be the servant of other men.

passages.zh: 人役而恥為役，由弓人而恥為弓，矢人而恥為矢也。
passages.en: To be the servant of men and yet ashamed of such servitude, is like a bowmaker's being ashamed to make bows, or an arrow-maker's being ashamed to make arrows.

passages.zh: 如恥之，莫如為仁。
passages.en: If he be ashamed of his case, his best course is to practise benevolence.

passages.zh: 仁者如射，射者正己而後發。
passages.en: The man who would be benevolent is like the archer. The archer adjusts himself and then shoots.

passages.zh: 發而不中，不怨勝己者，反求諸己而已矣。」
passages.en: If he misses, he does not murmur against those who surpass himself. He simply turns round and seeks the cause of his failure in himself.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「子路，人告之以有過則喜。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'When any one told Zi Lu that he had a fault, he rejoiced.

passages.zh: 禹聞善言則拜。
passages.en: When Yu heard good words, he bowed to the speaker.

passages.zh: 大舜有大焉，善與人同。
passages.en: The great Shun had a still greater delight in what was good. He regarded virtue as the common property of himself and others,

passages.zh: 舍己從人，樂取於人以為善。
passages.en: giving up his own way to follow that of others, and delighting to learn from others to practise what was good.

passages.zh: 自耕、稼、陶、漁以至為帝，無非取於人者。
passages.en: From the time when he ploughed and sowed, exercised the potter's art, and was a fisherman, to the time when he became emperor, he was continually learning from others.

passages.zh: 取諸人以為善，是與人為善者也。
passages.en: To take example from others to practise virtue, is to help them in the same practice.

passages.zh: 故君子莫大乎與人為善。」
passages.en: Therefore, there is no attribute of the superior man greater than his helping men to practise virtue.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「伯夷，非其君不事，非其友不友。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Bo Yi would not serve a prince whom he did not approve, nor associate with a friend whom he did not esteem.

passages.zh: 不立於惡人之朝，不與惡人言。
passages.en: He would not stand in a bad prince's court, nor speak with a bad man.

passages.zh: 立於惡人之朝，與惡人言，如以朝衣朝冠坐於塗炭。
passages.en: To stand in a bad prince's court, or to speak with a bad man, would have been to him the same as to sit with his court robes and court cap amid mire and ashes.

passages.zh: 推惡惡之心，思與鄉人立，其冠不正，望望然去之，若將浼焉。
passages.en: Pursuing the examination of his dislike to what was evil, we find that he thought it necessary, if he happened to be standing with a villager whose cap was not rightly adjusted, to leave him with a high air, as if he were going to be defiled.

passages.zh: 是故諸侯雖有善其辭命而至者，不受也。
passages.en: Therefore, although some of the princes made application to him with very proper messages, he would not receive their gifts.

passages.zh: 不受也者，是亦不屑就已。
passages.en: He would not receive their gifts, counting it inconsistent with his purity to go to them.

passages.zh: 柳下惠，不羞汙君，不卑小官。
passages.en: Hui of Liu Xia was not ashamed to serve an impure prince, nor did he think it low to be an inferior officer.

passages.zh: 進不隱賢，必以其道。
passages.en: When advanced to employment, he did not conceal his virtue, but made it a point to carry out his principles.

passages.zh: 遺佚而不怨，阨窮而不憫。
passages.en: When neglected and left without office, he did not murmur. When straitened by poverty, he did not grieve.

passages.zh: 故曰：『爾為爾，我為我，雖袒裼裸裎於我側，爾焉能浼我哉？』
passages.en: Accordingly, he had a saying,"You are you, and I am I. Although you stand by my side with breast and aims bare, or with your body naked, how can you defile me?"

passages.zh: 故由由然與之偕而不自失焉，援而止之而止。
passages.en: Therefore, self-possessed, he companied with men indifferently, at the same time not losing himself. When he wished to leave, if pressed to remain in office, he would remain.

passages.zh: 援而止之而止者，是亦不屑去已。」
passages.en: He would remain in office, when pressed to do so, not counting it required by his purity to go away.'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「伯夷隘，柳下惠不恭。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Bo Yi was narrow-minded, and Hui of Liu Xia was wanting in self-respect.

passages.zh: 隘與不恭，君子不由也。」
passages.en: The superior man will not manifest either narrow-mindedness, or the want of self-respect.'
